Only about 16,000 out of the initial 1.5 million earned semifinalist status.

Holman’s newspaper is produced by the after-school newspaper club. The 2019-2020 staff members were (front row, L-R) Gabrielle Kellner, Anastasiya Richardson and Jessika Williams; (back row) Glenn Changar (sponsor), Esme' Hurlbut, Samantha Lee, Alexandria Wilson and Sydney Hoynacki (editor-in-chief). They were able to watch it and then complete the following assignment: “Draw a picture of a time you had to wait.” Their responses were then sent back to Gartland and she was able to post comments to their work.

The technology problems are being addressed and most students have been able to rejoin their Zoom meetings.

Zoom is the online platform students will be using for class meetings during virtual learning. The virtual background feature in Zoom allows users to display an image as the background during Zoom meetings. We've created a series of background images for you to download and show off your Pirate Pride.

How to Download: 1) Right click on the image of your choice. 2) Click "Save Image As" and save it to your desired location (desktop, downloads, a folder).

How to Set Downloaded Image as Backdrop in Zoom: 1) After launching a Zoom meeting, click on ^ next to "Stop Video" on the bottom left of your Zoom window and select "Choose Virtual Background." 2) Click on the + on the right-hand side below the current image in your settings. 3) Click "Add Image." 4) Find your saved image and select it.

Ms. Libby Hilker started preparing her second grade virtual classroom at Remington Traditional by painting a mural on the walls this summer.

“Rumple Buttercup always sees himself as weird and in the end, he learns to celebrate his weirdness which I thought was perfect for virtual learning because we are all figuring out how to work in this weird world that we've never been in before,” she said. “We're definitely going to take it and make the best of it and try to find some creativity and celebrate that weirdness.”

She spent about 30 hours tracing it out and painting the details.

“I hope my kids like it,” she said. “I thought it was a little bit nicer than just some plain colors.”

Social media agrees as a post she made about it has gone viral.

“I have 13,000 likes on it already and the video was viewed over 30,000 times.”

She said she loves the book and can’t wait to share it with her students.

“I can integrate the curriculum with it with imagery because they describe the characters and then use it for the social aspects, too.”

GREAT GRADUATES Bob Behnken (Pattonville High School, Class of 1988) is preparing to return to Earth aboard the SpaceX Crew Dragon vehicle with fellow NASA astronaut Doug Hurley. They will undock from the International Space Station today and will splashdown on Aug. 2 ending NASA’s first crewed mission aboard a commercial spacecraft.

He has been in space since lifting off in the Falcon 9 rocket on May 30 and docking with the space station on May 31.

Having now performed 10 spacewalks, Behnken matched the U.S. record for the most performed by an American and is ranked fourth on the all-time, worldwide list for total time on spacewalks with 61 hours and 10 minutes.

Continuous coverage begins for the SpaceX Crew Dragon DM-2 return home from the International Space Station at 4:15 p.m. on NASA - National Aeronautics and Space Administration’s website. Hatch closure is scheduled for 4:45 p.m.; undocking scheduled at 6:34 p.m.; and splashdown on Aug. 2 is scheduled at 1:42 p.m. Click here to watch: https://www.nasa.gov/nasalive

Congratulations to senior Emily Schrumpf who was selected as the St. Louis Post-Dispatch Scholar Athlete from Pattonville High School. She has been a member of the varsity soccer team for all four years of her high school career, including two as captain and was named All-Conference Second Team in the 2019 season. Additionally, Schrumpf is a member of NHS (National Honor Society), Rho Kappa (the National Social Studies Honor Society), GALXC (Girls As Leaders Not Captains), SIT (School Improvement Team) and STUCO (Student Council) and is her class vice president. She also maintains a high GPA, including being first in her class unweighted and fifth weighted.

The St. Louis Post-Dispatch Scholar Athlete program honors one student from every area school, a requirement being that they participate in athletics and excel in the classroom. At Pattonville, coaches submit nominations and then vote to select the district’s honoree.

post_text: NASA - National Aeronautics and Space Administration astronauts Doug Hurley and 1988 Pattonville High School alumnus Bob Behnken will board Crew Dragon for the SpaceX Demo-2 mission to the International Space Station on May 27. This will be the first mission to launch NASA astronauts to orbit from the United States in nearly a decade. Behnken will be the “joint operations commander” for the mission, responsible for rendezvous, docking and undocking, as well as other activities while the spacecraft is docked to the station.

GREAT GRADUATES Thank you to Kayla Hinckley (Pattonville High School, Class of 2008) and Rachael Schaefer (Class of 2009) for taking care of our students and the community.

Hinckley works as the school nurse at Pattonville Early Childhood. Since school has been closed, she has stepped up to help at Ranken Jordan Pediatric Bridge Hospital. She is available virtually as a school nurse during the day and has been caring for the children at Ranken Jordan overnight.

Schaefer is currently the school nurse at Rose Acres Elementary. While school is not currently in session due to COVID-19, she is working part-time at Ranken Jordan Pediatric Bridge Hospital to help cover the needs on the floor.

Both alumnae went to school together, reunited working together at Ranken Jordan and then at Pattonville, and continue to pitch-in at Ranken Jordan when school isn’t in session.

Like many families during the current global pandemic, Mary Sosman is trying to find a new normal, balancing working from home while supporting at-home learning for her own children. Sosman is an English language learner specialist at Drummond Elementary School, but also has a 6-year-old kindergartner and an 8-year-old second grader at home to support.

“It’s been a lot to juggle and my teacher-student ratio is stellar, but add working on top and it's a lot,” Sosman said.

Sosman and families across the U.S. are discovering what works in navigating at-home learning with their own children while still working either at home or in the workplace. She and other staff in Pattonville provided advice on how to be successful at balancing both worlds in this new era of social distancing.

Their advice boils down to three big steps:
1) Create your new normal.
2) Reach out for help.
3) Take care of you.

A Pattonville Elementary Schools Robotics Tournament will be held at Holman Middle School on Saturday from 8 a.m. to noon. There are five teams participating in the event including one from Drummond Elementary.

The object of the game this year is to have the robot grab balls and put them on a cube. The team members also have to move that cube from wherever it is on the field to a highlighted area.

Fifth grader Dannia Flores was driving the robot during a practice session on Thursday and scored twice.

"It's really difficult to remember what the controls do, but the controller is a lot like a PS4 controller," she said. "It's exciting when you do it right and you can help your team."

She's hoping for the same results this weekend.

"I get really nervous during competitions and I always tell myself, 'If you don't do good, something will happen to you,' but nothing ever happens to me," she said. "It's going to be just a nice little friendly competition on Saturday."

Other schools participating are Bridgeway Elementary School, Rose Acres Elementary and Remington Traditional.

Dan Killeen of Happy Fun Books visited with the Bridgeway Elementary School kindergarten, first and second graders, and he must've known the theme of the school's dress up day for Read Across America Week. Wearing a red pullover, he matched all of the students wearing red because you can't spell reading without R E D.

After his presentation, he read his book "Tillie & Clementine: Noises in the Night" and then did a custom drawing for the school to keep while answering questions from the audience.

It was first grader Ellaha Sajid's first time meeting a real author and she thought the experience was awesome.

"I even got to ask him a question," she said. "I asked him how he did all the colorings in his book."

She enjoyed hearing the story read to her by the author himself.

"I liked the part in the book when Tillie and Clementine were throwing their toys on their dad."

Congratulations to Devin Garner, a fourth grade student in PEGS - Program for Exceptionally Gifted Students at Rose Acres Elementary. He placed third in the Grade 3-5 Division for the Gifted Association of Missouri (GAM) Student Legislative Letter Contest. The top three students in each division were recognized at the Capitol in Jefferson City during a meeting in the rotunda.

Garner wrote and sent letters to both his senator and representative in support of House Bill 1317 and Senate Bill 645 affecting gifted educational programming in Missouri.

He was recognized at the Capitol on Wednesday during GAM Day and had the opportunity to meet and speak with his representative, Representative Jay Mosley, of District 68 about his ideas.

Pictured is (left to right) Daren Garner (father), Devin Garner, and Daren Garner (grandfather) with Representative Jay Mosley (back).

Several Pattonville School District educators are attending the METC - Midwest EdTech Community (METC) Conference in St. Charles from Feb. 10-12.

METC is an annual event for those that are interested in educational technology, STEM careers, creativity, innovation and design thinking.

Every year, more than 2,000 people register for the event that offers over 200 learning opportunities.

Today, Pattonville High School science teacher Mr. Rob Lamb filled in for Pattonville High School assistant principal Dr. Jon Fitzgerald to present "Experimental Learning: SeaPerch Underwater Robotics."

"Events like METC allow you to connect with other educators," Lamb said. "Whenever I come to these things, I always learn more than I teach. It's worth every minute that we're here."

Remington Traditional and Willow Brook Elementary technology specialist Ms. Stephanie McCreary will be presenting a session titled "Student-Centered Team App Challenge Project" on Wednesday.

Their flight on the company's Crew Dragon spaceship scheduled for this spring will mark the first time an American spacecraft has carried NASA astronauts since the Space Shuttle program ended in 2011.

The district’s Cultural Proficiency Committee met today to learn, practice and develop ways to better serve diverse students, their families and the Pattonville community.

“We work on trying to help support cultural proficiency throughout our buildings and our district as a whole by improving our own understanding and improving the way we can serve all of our students and the community,” director of secondary education Dr. Cara Hiripitiyage said.

The Cultural Proficiency Committee is made up of certified staff, support staff and administrators from throughout the district.

“Today, we're practicing using breakthrough questions, which help people dialogue about culture and differences,” she said.

This committee has been working with professionals for more than two years on improving cultural proficiency.

“This work helps all staff grow personally and supports positive conversations about culture and understanding others,” Hiripitiyage said. “Teachers can take this work into their buildings and classrooms to help all learn and grow.”

Rather than just a day of celebrating reading in March for National Read Across America Day, Drummond Elementary organizes monthly celebrations throughout the entire year. For January, the theme was “Hibernation” and on Wednesday, students were invited to wear their pajamas to school when classes read nonfiction books about winter and animals that hibernate.

In the library, the bookshelves were decorated like a cave.

“We read a book to students about a bear who hibernates and whose friend is going to miss him while he’s gone,” library technology specialist Ms. Tammi Buckner said. “It was a perfect tie-in to the hibernation theme.”

After the reading, students grabbed a flashlight and went searching for a book they wanted to check out.

Kindergartener Liam Burnett picked “Suppose You Meet a Dinosaur” while wearing his dinosaur pajamas.

“It was awesome and super cool,” he said. “I had to use my flashlight because the cave was really dark and I loved it.”
